><snip>
>Now for the "count-assert" mechanism: I don't think that adding a 
>plug-in is the way to go.  The easiest way is to declare a static 
>variable in the Assert class.  This variable is accessible by the 
>CoreRunner and adding methods to handle this variable in the CoreRunner 
>object is not a problem.
></smip>
>
>But doesn't this break your code every time you upgrade JUnit?  I thought
>the point of a plug-in was that you could upgrade without having to make any
>code changes.
>
This does break the code if it is not included into the source code of 
JUnit, of course.  2 solutions here:
1) implement the count in the official JUnit code
2) implement a "manager only" version of JUnit.  (only a TextUI for ex.)

The framework should be now pretty stable and having a version "for 
managers only" is thinkable.  But I have to think about one more time 
:-)  Maybe with if (manager_version) count++ ... and see what the 
compiler generates.  If it can be done like in C++ (with #ifdef) it's 
not a big problem (just a couple of changes in the makefile).

-Vladimir
